author: nikonthethird
body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

When creating a `Runspace` from a completely empty `InitialSessionState` (`InitialSessionState.Create()`), the `CommandCompletion` should not find any completions, since the runspace does not contain any commands, aliases, types, variables, functions or even assemblies.

However, it still returns all the results it can find on my machine (C# console example with Nuget package [Microsoft.PowerShell.SDK](https://www.nuget.org/packages/Microsoft.PowerShell.SDK) installed):

```C#
using System;
using System.Management.Automation;
using System.Management.Automation.Runspaces;

var emptySessionState = InitialSessionState.Create();

Runspace.DefaultRunspace = RunspaceFactory.CreateRunspace(emptySessionState);
Runspace.DefaultRunspace.Open();

var commandCompletion = CommandCompletion.CompleteInput(input: "get-a", cursorIndex: 5, default);
foreach (var completion in commandCompletion.CompletionMatches) {
    Console.WriteLine($"Completion match: {completion.CompletionText}");
}
Console.WriteLine($"Found {commandCompletion.CompletionMatches.Count} completions in total.");
```

More information: The `CommandCompletion.CompleteInput` creates a `PowerShell` instance [using the thread static `Runspace`](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/cf527b23d96b3c99df9383fa3d045f3a4452bb79/src/System.Management.Automation/engine/CommandCompletion/CommandCompletion.cs#L525), that's why I set `Runspace.DefaultRunspace` above. The code will throw an exception otherwise. Since it uses the `Runspace` I just created from an empty session state, I expect the completions to take that into account as well.

### Expected behavior

```console
Found 0 completions in total.
```


### Actual behavior

```console
... # lots of lines above here
Completion match: Get-AzWebPubSubSku
Completion match: Get-AzWebPubSubUsage
Completion match: Az.Sql\Get-AzSqlDatabaseVulnerabilityAssessmentSetting
Completion match: Az.Sql\Get-AzSqlInstanceDatabaseVulnerabilityAssessmentSetting
Completion match: Az.Sql\Get-AzSqlServerAdvancedThreatProtectionSetting
Found 1108 completions in total.
```


### Error details

_No response_

### Environment data

```powershell
Not really applicable to the C# code, but I tried SDK version `7.2.5` and `7.3.0-preview.5`, same issue. But, since I don't want the issue to be rejected on a technicality, here is the `$PSVersionTable` output of my system:


Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.2.5
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.2.5
OS                             Linux 5.13.0-52-generic #59~20.04.1-Ubuntu SMP Thu Jun 16 21:21:28 UTC 2022
Platform                       Unix
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```


### Visuals

_No response_

comments.author: SeeminglyScience
comments.body: Completions are based on what can be invoked rather than what is currently loaded. You can try setting [`$PSModuleAutoloadingPreference`](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/microsoft.powershell.core/about/about_preference_variables?view=powershell-7.2#psmoduleautoloadingpreference) though I'm unsure if that changes completion.

comments.author: nikonthethird
comments.body:
Yes, that does indeed work!
Thank you very much!

```c#
initialSessionState.Variables.Add(new SessionStateVariableEntry(
    "PSModuleAutoLoadingPreference",
    PSModuleAutoLoadingPreference.None,
    default
));
```

title: CommandCompletion.CompleteInput finds a lot of results even with empty Runspace
